segment.source: Create a list of apps deployed to each business group (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create a list of apps deployed to each business group (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic describes the process of gathering app usage requirements from each business group in order to implement application control policies by using AppLocker.
segment.target: This topic describes the process of gathering app usage requirements from each business group in order to implement application control policies by using AppLocker.

segment.source: Create a list of apps deployed to each business group
segment.target: Create a list of apps deployed to each business group

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic describes the process of gathering app usage requirements from each business group in order to implement application control policies by using AppLocker.
segment.target: This topic describes the process of gathering app usage requirements from each business group in order to implement application control policies by using AppLocker.

segment.source: Determining app usage
segment.target: Determining app usage

segment.source: For each business group, determine the following:
segment.target: For each business group, determine the following:

segment.source: The complete list of apps used, including different versions of an app
segment.target: The complete list of apps used, including different versions of an app

segment.source: The full installation path of the app
segment.target: The full installation path of the app

segment.source: The publisher and signed status of each app
segment.target: The publisher and signed status of each app

segment.source: The type of requirement the business groups set for each app, such as business critical, business productivity, optional, or personal.
segment.target: The type of requirement the business groups set for each app, such as business critical, business productivity, optional, or personal.

segment.source: It might also be helpful during this effort to identify which apps are supported or unsupported by your IT department, or supported by others outside your control.
segment.target: It might also be helpful during this effort to identify which apps are supported or unsupported by your IT department, or supported by others outside your control.

segment.source: A list of files or apps that require administrative credentials to install or run.
segment.target: A list of files or apps that require administrative credentials to install or run.

segment.source: If the file requires administrative credentials to install or run, users who cannot provide administrative credentials will be prevented from running the file even if the file is explicitly allowed by an AppLocker policy.
segment.target: If the file requires administrative credentials to install or run, users who cannot provide administrative credentials will be prevented from running the file even if the file is explicitly allowed by an AppLocker policy.

segment.source: Even with AppLocker policies enforced, only members of the Administrators group can install or run files that require administrative credentials.
segment.target: Even with AppLocker policies enforced, only members of the Administrators group can install or run files that require administrative credentials.

segment.source: How to perform the app usage assessment
segment.target: How to perform the app usage assessment

segment.source: Although you might already have a method in place to understand app usage for each business group, you will need to use this information to help create your AppLocker rule collection.
segment.target: Although you might already have a method in place to understand app usage for each business group, you will need to use this information to help create your AppLocker rule collection.

segment.source: AppLocker includes the Automatically Generate Rules wizard and the Audit only enforcement configuration to assist you with planning and creating your rule collection.
segment.target: AppLocker includes the Automatically Generate Rules wizard and the Audit only enforcement configuration to assist you with planning and creating your rule collection.

segment.source: Application inventory methods
segment.target: Application inventory methods

segment.source: Using the Automatically Generate Rules wizard quickly creates rules for the applications you specify.
segment.target: Using the Automatically Generate Rules wizard quickly creates rules for the applications you specify.

segment.source: The wizard is designed specifically to build a rule collection.
segment.target: The wizard is designed specifically to build a rule collection.

segment.source: You can use the Local Security Policy snap-in to view and edit the rules.
segment.target: You can use the Local Security Policy snap-in to view and edit the rules.

segment.source: This method is very useful when creating rules from a reference computer, and when creating and evaluating AppLocker policies in a testing environment.
segment.target: This method is very useful when creating rules from a reference computer, and when creating and evaluating AppLocker policies in a testing environment.

segment.source: However, it does require that the files be accessible on the reference computer or through a network drive.
segment.target: However, it does require that the files be accessible on the reference computer or through a network drive.

segment.source: This might mean additional work in setting up the reference computer and determining a maintenance policy for that computer.
segment.target: This might mean additional work in setting up the reference computer and determining a maintenance policy for that computer.

segment.source: Using the Audit only enforcement method permits you to view the logs because it collects information about every process on the computers receiving the Group Policy Object (GPO).
segment.target: Using the Audit only enforcement method permits you to view the logs because it collects information about every process on the computers receiving the Group Policy Object (GPO).

segment.source: Therefore, you can see what the enforcement will be on the computers in a business group.
segment.target: Therefore, you can see what the enforcement will be on the computers in a business group.

segment.source: AppLocker includes Windows PowerShell cmdlets that you can use to analyze the events from the event log and cmdlets to create rules.
segment.target: AppLocker includes Windows PowerShell cmdlets that you can use to analyze the events from the event log and cmdlets to create rules.

segment.source: However, when you use Group Policy to deploy to several computers, a means to collect events in a central location is very important for manageability.
segment.target: However, when you use Group Policy to deploy to several computers, a means to collect events in a central location is very important for manageability.

segment.source: Because AppLocker logs information about files that users or other processes start on a computer, you could miss creating some rules initially.
segment.target: Because AppLocker logs information about files that users or other processes start on a computer, you could miss creating some rules initially.

segment.source: Therefore, you should continue your evaluation until you can verify that all required applications that are allowed to run are accessed successfully.
segment.target: Therefore, you should continue your evaluation until you can verify that all required applications that are allowed to run are accessed successfully.

segment.source: Tip: If you run Application Verifier against a custom application with any AppLocker policies enabled, it might prevent the application from running.
segment.target: Tip: If you run Application Verifier against a custom application with any AppLocker policies enabled, it might prevent the application from running.

segment.source: You should either disable Application Verifier or AppLocker.
segment.target: You should either disable Application Verifier or AppLocker.

segment.source: You can create an inventory of Universal Windows apps on a device by using two methods: the Get-AppxPackage Windows PowerShell cmdlet or the AppLocker console.
segment.target: You can create an inventory of Universal Windows apps on a device by using two methods: the Get-AppxPackage Windows PowerShell cmdlet or the AppLocker console.

segment.source: The following topics in the AppLocker Step-by-Step Guide describe how to perform each method:
segment.target: The following topics in the AppLocker Step-by-Step Guide describe how to perform each method:

segment.source: Automatically generating executable rules from a reference computer
segment.target: Automatically generating executable rules from a reference computer

segment.source: Using auditing to track which apps are used
segment.target: Using auditing to track which apps are used

segment.source: Prerequisites to completing the inventory
segment.target: Prerequisites to completing the inventory

segment.source: Identify the business group and each organizational unit (OU) within that group to which you will apply application control policies.
segment.target: Identify the business group and each organizational unit (OU) within that group to which you will apply application control policies.

segment.source: In addition, you should have identified whether or not AppLocker is the most appropriate solution for these policies.
segment.target: In addition, you should have identified whether or not AppLocker is the most appropriate solution for these policies.

segment.source: For info about these steps, see the following topics:
segment.target: For info about these steps, see the following topics:

segment.source: Understand AppLocker policy design decisions
segment.target: Understand AppLocker policy design decisions

segment.source: Determine your application control objectives
segment.target: Determine your application control objectives

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: Identify and develop the list of apps.
segment.target: Identify and develop the list of apps.

segment.source: Record the name of the app, whether it is signed or not as indicated by the publisher's name, and whether or not it is a mission critical, business productivity, optional, or personal application.
segment.target: Record the name of the app, whether it is signed or not as indicated by the publisher's name, and whether or not it is a mission critical, business productivity, optional, or personal application.

segment.source: Record the installation path of the apps.
segment.target: Record the installation path of the apps.

segment.source: For info about how to do this, see Document your app list.
segment.target: For info about how to do this, see Document your app list.

segment.source: After you have created the list of apps, the next step is to identify the rule collections, which will become the policies.
segment.target: After you have created the list of apps, the next step is to identify the rule collections, which will become the policies.

segment.source: This information can be added to the table under columns labeled:
segment.target: This information can be added to the table under columns labeled:

segment.source: Use default rule or define new rule condition
segment.target: Use default rule or define new rule condition

segment.source: Allow or deny
segment.target: Allow or deny

segment.source: GPO name
segment.target: GPO name

segment.source: To do this, see the following topics:
segment.target: To do this, see the following topics:

segment.source: Select the types of rules to create
segment.target: Select the types of rules to create

segment.source: Determine the Group Policy structure and rule enforcement
segment.target: Determine the Group Policy structure and rule enforcement
